body:
Hello @boglesby,
Can you review the requested changes?, are we good to go and merge the pull request now?.
Best regards.
LGTM
precheckin is green
Failures in Travic CI and "Test" job of precheckin are due to a known failure that has been fixed on develop since this PR was made.
Has this PR had a clean precheckin that's not shown in this PR history?

No, it looks like this didn't fix the issues with the AcceptanceTest

On Thu, Jul 5, 2018 at 10:32 AM, Kenneth Howe <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Has this PR had a clean precheckin that's not shown in this PR history?
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/geode/pull/2102#issuecomment-402797439>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AQGwNsnacWuLVPqq2naezE19sc5O0dTMks5uDk24gaJpZM4VBsC_>
> .
>
precheckin green
Pre-checkin green

@jinmeiliao Did you run the test a bunch to find out if it's indeed not flaky anymore? Your commit messages reads to me like the reasoning was that because there was a legitimate failure the test is not flaky. These things don't seem mutually exclusive to me.
UI and acceptance test failures are not related to this change.
There were problems with the apache concourse test runs but my own precheckin test run was green
the failure was corrected by later commits. the test hasn't been failing for a long time. and all the other tickets related to this test being flaky is marked as resolved and closed.
Pre-checkin green
@jujoramos Hi Juan, can you please resolve any conflicts and then I'll merge your changes in. Thanks!
precheckin green, please review again
Looks like this PR isn't needed, acceptance test is working.
@upthewaterspout @PurelyApplied @jinmeiliao @WireBaron

It could be incorporated here or elsewhere.  I partly wanted to spur a conversation with it.

Given that none of our precheckin or pipeline tests cover the Suites, it seems like bloat to have any.  This particular one could be reworked with a `Parameterized` class rule toggling that `ProvideSystemProperty` on and off.  Since the codebase's other Suites are empty, perhaps they should be removed outright?

I suppose this might be more something for the dev list and a separate ticket, but I'd love to hear your thoughts.
precheckin green
precheckin green
@nabarunnag @kirklund please see if later changes are good. Thanks!
rebased to develop and precheckin green

I still want to review the gradle changes, but one thing we should probably do with this PR is just diff the tests that got run as part of the above checks with the develop pipeline at the same revision. If we're not missing any tests I think we're good.

@upthewaterspout I have tried to do that along the way. What I found was there were tests that overlapped primary categories or had the wrong primary category (integration when they really were distributed). On top of that people keep adding or fixing tests so the counts and lists of tests is a moving target. The number of tests are within a few of previous runs in each category. Some more, some less, some the same.
@jinmeiliao @upthewaterspout @WireBaron @PurelyApplied
@jinmeiliao @upthewaterspout @PurelyApplied
@jujoramos: There were a lot of failures in the CI runs, but I'm not sure they are related to your changes. I'm running a manual preckeckin right now.
The 1 failure in the `concourse-ci/DistributedTest` CI passes normally. It looks like the CI is having resource issues.
Test numbers are still lining up compared to those based on the old categories.
FYI the concourse jobs failed, but they have nothing to do with this change. Looks like concourse is overloaded.
Changed commit message
Precheckin green (on old precheckin, failing some known-issue tests on the new precheckin)
It looks like concourse if having problems downloading stuff for gradle. The code "ran on my machine".
This is for improving runtime of dunit tests that would use less vm than the default 4? I somehow still like the convenience of having a no-arg constructor of the rule.

The plug-in was added, but is not publishing anywhere by default

On Jul 12, 2018 16:38, "Dan Smith" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

*@upthewaterspout* approved this pull request.

It looks like you added a build-scan plugin in this PR as well? That's ok
as long as it's not publishing scans somewhere without developer's consent.

â€”

Hello @boglesby ,

That's weird, `precheckin` was running 100% correctly when I requested the changes to be reviewed last time. I'm on vacations right now, will update that particular test you mentioned and re-submit the changes in around two weeks.
Cheers.

Hello @kirklund,

I'm on vacations at the moment so won't be able to merge the conflicts right now (they didn't exist when I submitted the pull request and the changes requested, anyway), will do in approximately two weeks from now.
Cheers.
@rhoughton-pivot
@dschneider-pivotal Do we still want this? It's not clear to me from PR and commit messages why you were making these changes. Can you either close or fix â†’ merge this?
The test that is failing was added 05/24/2018.
@nabarunnag This seems to be adding some valuable tests. Could you either fix â†’ merge or close this and "won't fix" the Geode ticket?

@yossireg Do you think you can make some time to address the outstanding concerns or would you rather close this for now?
Thanks for your contribution!
The repackage caused hard to diagnose rolling upgrade issues. Closing this for now.
(Finn was involved in those commits.  I just forgot to include the `co-authored by:` in the commit message.)
@nabarunnag Not sure how much time it would take to address Kirk's suggestion. What do you think about either fixing and merging this or closing?
@nabarunnag The associated ticket is closed, meanwhile this is still open and has valid requests. Should this be closed since the ticket indicates the work is done?
@nabarunnag Looks like a lot of good work went into this, but hasn't even gotten any reviews yet. Do you want to add some reviewers and move this along or do you think it's not needed anymore?
@jdeppe-pivotal Seems like this is bad now. Since it's so close to the finish line, do you want to fix it and get it merged?
`DistributedTest` failure from known issue in GEODE-577 resulting in `QueryMonitorDUnitTest.testQueryMonitorClientServer`.
@PurelyApplied Thoughts on addressing Jen's suggestions and merging vs closing?
@karensmolermiller This hasn't seen any activity in a while and seems so close to the finish line. Do you want incorporate Dan's suggestions (or not) and merge or should this be closed?
@upthewaterspout @mcmellawatt @WireBaron @PurelyApplied Please review...

`DistributedTest` failed to GEODE-577, "superflaky" `QueryMonitorDUnitTest.testQueryMonitorClientServer`, and GEODE-2275, semi-flaky `ClearTXLockingDUnitTest.testPutWithClearDifferentVM`.

`IntegrationTest` failed with an apparent hang, but without the `capture-call-stacks.sh` invoking before the concourse job timed out.  This may suggest Concourse instability as the root cause.

Adding an empty commit to re-trigger precheckin.  We should consider prioritizing GEODE-2275.

I'm getting this failure intermittently:

Precheckin fails for `UITests` on `PulseAutomatedTest. testClusterNumSubscriptions`, a Flaky test receiving attention under GEODE-5417. This should be okay to merge. @upthewaterspout
I will handle it shortly , please remain it open
precheckin is green
precheckin green
This was merged to develop but not closed. This was to fix a design issue with the feature implementation with the same geode ticket number. this issue was caught by test failures.
@pivotal-amurmann This is the fix to  a feature development for lucene reindex. I am currently working on this.
Opened ticket for flaky test in CI distributedTest https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-5440.
Looks good. Passes build and test on my end
Can you rename this PR to be the GEODE-#: Description format?
@upthewaterspout @jinmeiliao  Please review this PR when you get the chance.
@upthewaterspout @smgoller @jinmeiliao

After discussion with @monkeyherder, we came to the conclusion that having this job as part of the PR pipeline isn't useful, and this should be removed from that, and run as a calendar-triggered job that runs once a day or once a week and doesn't affect the pipeline status.
Good point Dan, I just replaced the method with region.get calls.
We will be making significant changes to this implementation to provide a better API. I will send a proposal for the API to the geode dev list. Closing this PR for now.

Can't someone just run these tests manually themselves? If we are pulling these tests out because they are flaky and we don't think they have much value, we should just remove them from concourse entirely.
@upthewaterspout @jinmeiliao @galen-pivotal  Please review this PR when you get the chance.
Checked all the prior failures and individually the tests ran successfully.

@upthewaterspout not everyone has access to trigger job manually. 

Until they are made stable they provide no useful feedback. At the very least they should come off the PR because we would be telling people to ignore red PR CI which is bad. If we keep them on the main CI at least the release manager can restart the job and make it green. Another option is to add to either or both pipelines the concept of "rerun failed tests".

@pivotal-jbarrett - Hmm, maybe you misunderstood my comment. I'm saying the same thing that you are, we shouldn't be running these tests in any concourse jobs. If someone wants to run them, they can run them manually on their own computer.
Thanks for changing the typo in the code. Maybe fix the typo in the commit message ðŸ˜‰
Looks like the build is failing due to Spotless violations?
all required changes were implemented - please review it
@upthewaterspout @WireBaron @jinmeiliao @mcmellawatt  Can one of you merge this? I am not a committer.
@galen-pivotal @upthewaterspout Can one of you merge this? I am not a committer.

@upthewaterspout Your suggestion all but guarantees they are going to fall into disrepair. Even very rarely running them is better than nothing, the concession there, was to make a manually triggered CI. As it is far more public, I favor that approach. Also that way the build can easily be checked without tying up time running them locally for a one off check.
@WireBaron @upthewaterspout @jinmeiliao @galen-pivotal Please review this PR when it is green.
@rhoughton-pivot
LGTM, barring precheckin green.
@smgoller @balesh2
As long as it's call-compatible with the original it should be fine.

Hello @boglesby ,

I've double checked and that particular test was added **after** my changes and rebases but **before** the PR was merged, that's the reason why it was failing. Either way, there's been several changes over the past two weeks so I decided to rebase again and solve the conflicts locally, I'll submit a new commit shortly.
Best regards.
I'm running this through precheckin testing and, if there are no objections, I'll merge it to develop.
@pivotal-jbarrett Thanks for the review. I have updated this PR to implement using property.
I'm glad to see GfshRule is still getting some love :) ðŸ‘

Since Paramaterization and BeforeClass do not play well together, in some Cli tests which we test using http connection (on to of jmx) we do this by extending the test and overriding a connect method.
@jinmeiliao @upthewaterspout @balesh2 @WireBaron
This has been merged to develop: commit 143419e91d9c714338833b3a6cff598a7dc7f096
@balesh2 @mhansonp
Precheckin Green!
It looks like we are going to kill the UI test pipeline, so I'm closing this PR.
Can you rebase now that the rolling upgrade sourceSet pull has been merged:
rebased on develop
